sentences: Nicole Monique Wray (born May 2, 1979), also known as Lady Wray, is an American singer and songwriter.
Her 1998 debut single "Make It Hot" was certified gold.
Nicole Monique Wray was born on May 2, 1979, in Salinas, California, to Debra Wray (née Murphy) and Kenneth Wray.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: During her teenage years, Wray was introduced to then-upcoming rapper Missy Elliott, who was looking for a female singer to sign to her own recording label The Goldmind Inc.
section: == Early life ==

section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In 1997, Wray appeared as a featured vocalist on the song "Gettaway" for Missy Elliott's first album Supa Dupa Fly.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In June 1998, Wray released her first single "Make It Hot".
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: The single peaked in the top-five on Billboard's Hot 100, and received certified gold-status within six weeks of its release for a total of over 700,000 copies sold.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: On August 25, 1998, Wray released her first album Make It Hot.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: The album's follow-up singles "I Can't See" and "Eyes Better Not Wander" failed to crossover with the latter only peaking at seventy-one on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart in 1999.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In September 1999, Missy Elliott released her single "All n My Grill", which featured Wray, Big Boi, and MC Solaar.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In 2000, Wray began recording her original second album titled Elektric Blue.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In July 2001, she released the single "I'm Lookin'" which was planned to be the lead single.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: Following the single's moderate performance on the R&B chart, the album Elektric Blue was subjected to several postponed dates and was ultimately shelved when Wray decided to leave The Goldmind Inc and Elektra Records in 2001.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===

sentences: In 2002, gospel duo Pam & Dodi released "Don't Have To", a gospel and pop song written by Wray.
section: == Career == | === 1997–2002: Make It Hot and split from The Goldmind Inc./Elektra ===
== Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: In June 2003, Wray released a single "Welcome Home" with rapper Ol' Dirty Bastard.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: Later that year, Wray secured a recording contract with Roc-A-Fella Records.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: In November 2004, Wray released a single "If I Was Your Girlfriend", originally planned to be the lead single of her forthcoming album Lovechild.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: The single spent twenty weeks on R&B chart but ultimately peaked at fifty-seven.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: Later that year, Wray experienced a brief roster move from Roc-A Fella to Def Jam Records to ultimately the Dame Dash Music Group.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: The album Lovechild was scheduled to be released in April 2005 but was shelved after the Dame Dash Music Group became defunct.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: In July 2005, Wray and Mike Jones released a song called "Still Tippin' (It's a Man's World) (Remix)" on the soundtrack of American drama film Hustle & Flow.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: Still maintaining her work relationship with Damon Dash, Wray performed on The Black Keys rock and hip-hop fusion album titled Blakroc, released in November 2009.
section: == Career == | === 2003–2011: Lovechild ===

sentences: Wray was then enlisted to add her background vocals on The Black Keys' album, Brothers, which was released in May 2010.
